text:
It starts when Uncle Four starts coughing. They don't think much of it. People get ill sometimes. Wen Qing is able to give him medicinal tea and it never progresses beyond sniffles and a cough. It passes from person to person in their small settlement, never staying long, never making anyone so sick they need to do anything more than drink Wen Qing's tea and nap for a couple of afternoons. The cultivators amongst them don't get ill at all.
When Wei Wuxian falls sick, he just stays in his cave "inventing" for a couple of days. It's nothing unusual. No one but Wen Ning and Wen Qing even notice.
A-Yuan gets ill a few days after Wei Wuxian gets better. He gets sicker than the rest, but Wen Qing assures them that this is normal because of his age. Wei Wuxian spends hours telling him stories and holding him while he sleeps.
It's while A-Yuan is asleep on his chest that Wei Wuxian notices his breathing has become more labored, can feel his little body grow warmer.
He gets up without putting A-Yuan down and moves to the entrance of the cave.
"Wen Qing," he calls. A-Yuan doesn't so much as stir.
"What is it?" she demands.
"I think he's gotten worse," he says.
She frowns and checks his pulse, his temperature, and listens to his breathing. "Go back inside. I'll get a poultice for the breathing and more tea."
Wei Wuxian nods and does as he's told. It's not long before Wen Qing returns with the promised items. The poultice doesn't smell very good, but Wei Wuxian doesn't complain. They wake A-Yuan up enough for him to drink the tea. For the first time, he doesn't make faces at the taste, just drinks, then lets his head fall back to Wei Wuxian's shoulder and sleeps.
"Let me know if there's any change," Wen Qing instructs.
Things seem like they're improving and then A-Yuan's fever spikes. After that, neither of them leave A-Yuan for more time than it takes to get water or relieve themselves. Wen Ning fetches them fresh water and anything else his sister might need, but no matter what she tries, nothing helps bring down A-Yuan's fever for long.
"Wei Wuxian," she says as dawn starts to break. "I don't have the things we need to help him."
"I'll go to Yiling," Wei Wuxian says immediately. "Buy whatever it is."
She shakes her head, mouth pressed together in a thin line. "The doctor in Yiling would not have what is needed to treat this. Only a cultivation clan would have everything necessary.”
Wei Wuxian freezes. Yunmeng is closest, but he can't take this to Jiang Cheng. He knows he can't. There are plenty of smaller clans relatively nearby, but all of them hate and fear him, never mind that A-Yuan is a Wen. None would even let him in the door to beg his case.
There is only one option.
“I will take him to Gusu," Wei Wuxian says and gets up to start preparing to leave. "Lan Zhan likes A-Yuan. If nothing else, he would help."
"Wei Wuxian," Wen Qing says. "What if he's not there? The Lans–"
"Would not turn away a sick child," Wei Wuxian insists. "Even if I am the one who brings him. Unless you think–" Wei Wuxian stops and swallows hard. "Unless you think he couldn't make it to Gusu."
She shakes her head immediately. "If you follow my instructions exactly, he will make it."
"You should come," Wei Wuxian says. "Make sure."
"Then who will be here in case something happens? A-Ning wouldn't know what to do," she replies. "And don't suggest I go by myself, that would be stupid. I'll go prepare a bag with everything you'll need."
With that, she whirls out of the cave.
"We'll get you better, A-Yuan. Whatever it takes," Wei Wuxian promises the snuffling, sleeping form of the little boy huddled under the blankets on his bed. He throws stacks of talismans and anything he can think of that might be useful in a qiankun pouch. Wen Qing returns shortly thereafter with Granny and Wen Ning behind her.
Wei Wuxian tries to stay out of their way, to give them some time with him, but Granny calls for him and tugs him close.
"Take care of him," she says.
"I will give up my life before I let anything happen to him," he vows.
"Of course," she says and pats his cheek. "He is your child."
"Granny," he starts, but she puts two fingers over his lips.
"Hush," she says. "We all know it to be true. Just remember to take care of yourself, too. He's already lost one father. Don't make him lose another."
Wei Wuxian can't speak around the lump in his throat, so he nods and hugs back when Granny embraces him. Wen Ning runs his hand over A-Yuan's small head, then steps back.
"If anything happens, I'll be counting on you to protect everyone, Wen Ning," Wei Wuxian says.
"I will," Wen Ning promises.
Wei Wuxian claps him on the shoulder and leans down when Granny tugs on him. She puts a loop of fabric over his head and he recognizes it as the sling she uses to hold A-Yuan when he gets tired. Wen Qing lifts him from the bed and helps get him situated while giving him her instructions on how to take care of A-Yuan until they get to Gusu. Wen Ning tucks the remaining supplies into his qiankun bag.
"If the weather takes a turn for the worse, please stop somewhere. Rain or wind would do him no good. Even if you have to pay for a room at an inn." Wen Qing says, fussing with the fabric holding A-Yuan and the blanket he's wrapped in. Wen Qing suggesting he spend money only drives home how serious she is about it. "Don't do anything stupid. Send word when you arrive."
He nods. "I will."
"Go," she says. "Be swift."
He nods again, reaches to make sure Chenqing is in its spot on his belt, and heads out into the late afternoon sun. At least the weather is still relatively warm. He won't have to worry about the cold.
He makes his way down the hill. He pauses just outside the wards to make sure there are no gaps, that the Wens will be as safe and protected as possible while he is away, and then he's off.
He pushes hard, pausing only to take care of A-Yuan per Wen Qing's instructions, then moving again. He loses track of time completely. He stops only once when he's so tired he knows if he goes much longer, he'll start getting disoriented. He finds them an empty, falling-down shack and sleeps for a few hours before setting off again.
His exhaustion is starting to overcome him again when he reaches a town late in the evening. It's large enough to still have some activity in the streets, despite the lateness. It takes him nearly falling into the river bisecting the place to realize this isn't just any town. This is Caiyi Town.
"We're almost there, little man," Wei Wuxian breathes and kisses the top of A-Yuan's head. "Just a little bit further."
He takes a swig of water and lets himself catch his breath before setting out again. He's so close, it would be stupid to stop now. He can make it. He knows he can make it.
He almost regrets the decision when he gets to the base of the mountain upon which the Cloud Recesses sit, but he presses on.
"Wonder if the fact that normal people would have a harder time getting up here is by design or a happy accident," he grouses.
There's a constant ache in his chest from missing Suibian, but now it pulses. He'd have been here by now. A-Yuan would have already been receiving proper treatment for at least a day.
Stil, he puts one foot in front of the next and keeps climbing.
It feels like the top will never come, like he'll be climbing until he dies. This was much easier when he was fifteen–for too many reasons to count.
He nearly cries when he sees the light of the lanterns hanging at the gates of the Cloud Recesses. He allows himself a single moment of relief before the reality that now he has to talk his way in hits him.
"Fuck," he breathes. His only hope is getting them to go get Lan Wangji and Wei Wuxian doesn't even know if he's actually here.
"Good evening, pilgrim," one of the guards says. "Please state your business."
"I come seeking aid," Wei Wuxian says. "I have a very sick child."
"Step further into the light," another guard with a much less friendly voice says. He tugs the sling back so A-Yuan's head is visible and does as he's told.
"Wei Wuxian!" the unfriendly guard shouts and both guards draw their swords.
Every instinct is screaming for Wei Wuxian to grab Chenqing. He takes a deep breath instead. "Yes. I come only to beg for aid for my child."
"Why should we believe you?" the first, unfriendly guard asks.
Because you're not already dead, he does not say even though he wants to more than anything.
"Because he is here in my arms and obviously sick," Wei Wuxian replies through gritted teeth. "And if you think me so dangerous, go get Hanguang-Jun. Let him be the judge."
They confer for a moment. "Hanguang-Jun is asleep. Why should we wake him for the likes of you?"
"Because he has shown fondness for this child in the past and he would be upset with you for delaying. I will submit to whatever he chooses to do with me once he's here," Wei Wuxian says.
"Fine," the grumpy one says. "But if you so much as breathe in the wrong direction, I'm sounding the alarm."
Wei Wuxian nods. He keeps both hands where they can be seen and does not move except to press a kiss to A-Yuan's still too warm forehead.
It feels like hours, or maybe several years, pass before he hears the sound of the gate opening.
"Wei Ying?" Lan Wangji asks. He looks different. It takes Wei Wuxian an embarrassingly long moment of staring to realize it's because his hair isn't up in a headpiece. His forehead ribbon is, notably, still firmly in place.
"Lan Zhan," Wei Wuxian says, suddenly feeling heavy and sluggish. "Lan Zhan, please. He's sick. We didn't have the things needed to treat him and I couldn't think of anywhere else to go. I will beg if I must. I have no pride where A-Yuan is concerned."
To his horror, he feels his eyes burn and he sways on his feet.
"Wei Ying!" Lan Wangji gasps and suddenly he's very close and he puts an arm around his shoulders to steady him. "You need not beg. We will help."
The relief at those words is so great, Wei Wuxian feels like a puppet whose strings have been cut. He made it. The Lans will help.
*
When he went to bed earlier, Lan Wangji certainly did not expect to be woken up well before morning by a frantic guard proclaiming that the Yiling Patriarch was at the gates demanding to see him.

Wei Ying. 

He dresses quickly and as they walk, he manages to get more information out of the guard.
"He claims he has a sick child with him, but it's probably a trick," Zhang San says. "Why would there be a child with him and his army?"
"Have you been to Yiling?" Lan Wangji asks. "Have you seen his army?"
"Well...no," Zhang San replies.
"Well, I have," Lan Wangji replies. "This army you speak of is less than fifty people, largely old men who could not fight, and women. They were healers before the Sunshot Campaign. The child's name is A-Yuan. Do not make judgements based on unfounded rumors."
"Yes, Hanguang-Jun," Zhang San says quietly. "Sorry, Hanguang-Jun."
The rest of the walk is silent and not nearly fast enough. Finally, the gates come into view and he waves a hand to open them. There Wei Ying stands, A-Yuan held tightly in his arms. He looks beyond exhausted and rough in ways Lan Wangji hoped to never see again after the Sunshot Campaign.
"Wei Ying?" he says. Wei Wuxian looks up at him, stares for several long moments, then he blinks.
"Lan Zhan. Lan Zhan, please," Wei Wuxian says, voice hoarse. "He's sick. We didn't have the things needed to treat him and I couldn't think of anywhere else to go. I will beg if I must. I have no pride where A-Yuan is concerned."
Lan Wangji swallows hard and watches as Wei Wuxian's eyes go glassy and then he sways on his feet.
"Wei Ying!" Lan Wangji dashes forward and wraps an arm around Wei Wuxian's shoulders. "Wei Ying, you need not beg. We will help."
The relief that floods Wei Wuxian's eyes at that almost overwhelms him. It clearly overwhelms Wei Wuxian because his knees give out a bit and it takes Lan Wangji a moment to get him steady again.
"Sorry, Lan Zhan," he says. "I haven't slept in...a while."
"Fetch the doctor," Lan Wangji orders. "We will meet him at the medical pavilion."
He keeps his arm around Wei Wuxian as they make their way through the Cloud Recesses. The little boy in his arms is alarmingly still and silent, so unlike the way he was in Yiling. Lan Wangji hates it.
He wonders how long it's been since Wei Wuxian ate properly or slept. He doesn't have his sword, so he must have traveled on foot, which is a journey of at least four days.
"Why did you not ride Suibian?" Lan Wangji asks.
"Please don't ask me, Lan Zhan," Wei Wuxian replies. He sounds, impossibly, even more tired than he already had. "Anything else. Not that."
"All right," Lan Wangji replies softly. There's something off in that response. Before, when asked about Suibian, Wei Wuxian has reacted with anger, with defiance. He will let it be, for now. "Are there others who fell ill?"
"We all caught it. Well, not the cultivators, but everyone else got a cough and some sniffles. A few afternoon naps and it was gone," Wei Wuxian replies around a big yawn. "But not for A-Yuan. It got worse and then became what you see now."
The implication being that Wei Wuxian is not a cultivator, Lan Wangji realizes with dawning horror. Which would also explain why he can't ride Suibian. He is clearly too tired to properly censor himself. Lan Wangji swallows and voices none of this.
"How long has he been ill?" Lan Wangji asks instead.
"Over a week, now," he replies, then whines, "Lan Zhan, why is the medical pavilion so far?"
"It is not that far," Lan Wangji says. "You are merely very tired."
"I suppose. Better than back with those two at the gates. They were ready to fight me, even though I was clearly carrying a child," he says. "I'm probably lucky they even bothered to get you."
"But they did, so while they are young and foolish, they are not hopeless," Lan Wangji replies.
"What time is it, anyway? I woke you up. I'm sorry," he sounds genuinely contrite and Lan Wangji wants to shake him.
"It is fine," he replies and turns them down a short path to the medical pavilion building.
Wei Wuxian lays A-Yuan down on a bed and Lan Wangji watches him fuss with the blankets and push his hair back out of his face.
"Wei Ying," Lan Wangji says. "He will be fine now. The doctor will be here in a moment."
Wei Wuxian swallows visibly and nods. "Thank you for...I knew we could count on you."
"Wei Ying–"
The clan doctor clears his throat at the doorway just then and he watches Wei Wuxian scramble up to bow to him. Lan Wangji bows beside him.
"Doctor," Wei Wuxian says.
"Wei-gongzi," the doctor greets. Wei Wuxian doesn't recognize him, but that doesn't really mean much. He doesn't recognize a lot of people he's met.
"I'm sorry to disturb you so late, but my...A-Yuan. He's so sick. I have a letter from Wen Qing detailing the treatments she was able to give and her diagnosis." Wei Wuxian reaches into his sleeve and hands the doctor the letter.
The doctor reads it over quickly and moves forward toward the bed where A-Yuan is curled up. Wei Wuxian's entire demeanor changes in an instant. He goes stiff with tension and his hand moves to Chenqing. It occurs to him that since A-Yuan was taken from the Jin prison camp, it's very likely that Lan Wangji himself is the only stranger who has been allowed anywhere near A-Yuan.
"Wei Ying," Lan Wangji says and wraps a hand gently around his wrist. "I would not allow anyone to touch him if I did not trust them. I trust Lan Simiao."
"I know," Wei Wuxian replies and Lan Wangji can feel him forcing himself to relax, to take his hand away from his flute. "I know. I just–"
"Wei-gongzi, all I see here is a sick child. I will treat him with as much care as I did our Lan Wangji when he was a boy," the doctor says without looking up from his examination of A-Yuan. "You have nothing to fear from me."
"I'm sorry," Wei Wuxian says and takes a breath. "And thank you."
Lan Zhan doesn't move away, doesn't release his grip. He watches Wei Wuxian close his eyes and take slow, deep breaths.
After a thorough examination that probably doesn't take as long as it feels like it does, the doctor finally looks up. "Wen-daifu was correct in her assessment, as expected. He will make a full recovery if we begin treatment immediately."
"May I stay?" Wei Wuxian asks immediately
"If you can manage to keep out of the way," the doctor replies.
"You should get some rest," Lan Wangji suggests and squeezes his wrist slightly.
Wei Wuxian shakes his head. "I'll stay."
Lan Wangji's eyes bore into Wei Wuxian's, and he stares back.
And then Wei Ying sways on his feet again.
"Wei Ying!" he says once again, and slides an arm around him.
"'M fine," he replies, voice muffled in the fabric over Lan Wangji's shoulder. "Just not used to being upright without him anymore."
"Wei Ying, you must sleep," Lan Wangji says, feeling slightly desperate.
"I can't leave him," Wei Wuxian insists, shaking his head. "Lan Zhan, I can't."
"Wei Ying–"
"It is no use, Hanguang-Jun," the doctor says. "You will never convince a parent to leave their sick child."
"I'm not–"
"Lying is not permitted in the Cloud Recesses, young man," the doctor says tartly. "He may not be yours by blood, but anyone with eyes can see he is yours in every other way and I've known you for less time than it would take to eat a meal."
Wei Wuxian swallows audibly, and after a moment he lifts his eyes to look at Lan Wangji. There's an odd look of guilt there which Lan Wangji can't hope to decipher the cause of. He's known since that day in Yiling. Since Wei Ying's ridiculous joke that was only a joke insofar as the physical aspects of it went. The truth of it was shining bright in his eyes, in every action, every interaction with A-Yuan.
"I will fetch a few things to make you more comfortable here," Lan Wangji says, and turns his gaze to the doctor, "If that is all right with you?"
"As long as my medical pavilion remains quiet apart from the child," the doctor agrees. Lan Wangji nods and leads Wei Wuxian to a mat he found and placed near A-Yuan's bed.
"I'll be back," he promises.
"With food?" Wei Wuxian asks hopefully.
"And a bath and clean clothing," Lan Wangji promises.
"You really are the best," Wei Wuxian says, eyes shining with gratitude.
Lan Wangji nods at him, then the doctor, and slips out into the night again. Food, a bath, and a clean change of clothing is the bare minimum of courtesy, yet clearly Wei Wuxian does not expect more, not even from Lan Wangji whom he once called his soulmate.
Lan Wangji swallows and gathers everything he needs as swiftly as he can. Lan Wangji catches the two who were at the gates when Wei Wuxian arrived as the guard changes and presses them into service helping him. He knows he's being petty, but it's late and he's tired and despite Wei Wuxian's outwardly flippant attitude, Lan Wangji knows they upset him. They can have their sleep delayed longer in order to make Wei Ying more comfortable.
The likelihood of finding any food to Wei Ying's taste at this time of night is slim, but he does his best to put together a meal that won't actively repulse him.
He takes the tray back to the medical pavilion. Wei Wuxian is kneeling next to the bed and running his hand gently over A-Yuan's hair. His eyes snap immediately toward Lan Wangji and then he visibly relaxes.
"I have food," Lan Wangji offers.
"I feel simultaneously like I'm starving and like eating even a bite might make me nauseous," he says. "I suppose that means your bland Gusu food may actually be just the thing."
"Mn," Lan Wangji responds and sets the tray on the low table next to the bed. He stares at Wei Wuxian until he sighs, reaches for the bowl of congee, and takes a bite.
While he eats, Lan Wangji goes into another room and lays out the clean clothes and towel. The guards arrive with the tub and hot water a few moments later. Once it's set up and the tub is full, he returns to the main room.
The doctor comes back into the room with a tray of his own. It's clearly full of various treatments for A-Yuan, and he starts administering them with Wei Wuxian's assistance.
"The last is a poultice for his chest, but he should be bathed and clean before I put it on," the doctor says.
Wei Ying nods and shoots Lan Wangji an apologetic little smile. "I guess A-Yuan gets the nice bath you arranged first."
"I will get you fresh water," Lan Wangji says.
"You don't need to," Wei Wuxian dismisses. Lan Wangji doesn't bother responding. He will, of course, regardless of anything Wei Wuxian might say.
Wei Wuxian sweeps A-Yuan up into his arms and carries him into the other room. The doctor hands him some small, child-sized underrobes, then Lan Wangji follows.
"He's going to be so sad to have slept through this," Wei Wuxian murmurs as he strips A-Yuan of his dirty, worn, and slightly too-small clothes. "He loves baths and water. I would have started teaching him to swim already if we were at Lotus Pier."
Wei Ying sounds sadder than Lan Wangji ever wants to hear him sound.
"He can have as many baths as he likes when he wakes," Lan Wangji promises. The cold pond is not a suitable place to teach a child to swim for any number of reasons, but he would offer it as well if he could.
It turns out that the tub is deep enough that it will make holding an unconscious A-Yuan and washing him at the same time somewhat complicated.
"This is silly," Wei Wuxian finally declares and passes A-Yuan to Lan Wangji. "I'll just get in with him. Kill two birds with one stone."
Wei Wuxian starts stripping off his robe. Lan Wangji huffs and turns his head to the side. He hears a soft laugh and then hears the water splash as Wei Wuxian gets in the tub.
"Okay, Lan Zhan," he says. "Give him to me."
Lan Wangji does as he's asked and steps back, turning his head again.
"Lan Zhan, what have you been doing since we last saw each other?" Wei Wuxian asks as he bathes himself and A-Yuan.
"Night hunts. Study. Music practice," he answers. It's nothing terribly interesting or exciting. Even the night hunts were routine tasks with uninteresting creatures. Nothing that would capture Wei Wuxian's interest. "You?"
"Working on talismans. Testing Wen Ning's abilities. Playing with this one and getting yelled at by Wen Qing," he replies. "I...had some other visitors. On their way to Lanling for a wedding. It was good to see them."
Wei Wuxian's voice is thick and Lan Wangji doesn't have to look at his face to picture his expression.
"Ah, Lan Zhan," he says. "It's...I don't think I can wash my hair and hold him at the same time. Do it for me?"
Lan Wangji should offer to take A-Yuan. To let Wei Wuxian finish bathing himself.
He doesn't.
"All right," he agrees softly and moves behind Wei Wuxian.
"Oh," Wei Wuxian breathes. "You don't have to, I was–we can figure something out."
Lan Wangji ignores him and uses a jug to carefully wet his hair. He has to concentrate to keep his hands from trembling as he works soap through Wei Ying's hair.
It feels impossible that this is the most intimately Lan Wangji has ever touched Wei Wuxian, yet the way his heart is pounding proves otherwise. Now that he's done it, he never wants to stop touching Wei Wuxian like this. He wants, more than almost anything, to have the right to continue. To not need the excuse of a sick child to do so.
Wei Ying is curiously silent through the entire process.
"Wei Ying, have you fallen asleep?" he whispers.
"No, Lan Zhan," Wei Wuxian replies, voice barely a low rumble. "Feels nice."
Lan Wangji swallows and rinses Wei Ying's hair before running a comb gently through the strands. The water is going to start cooling soon and A-Yuan needs his poultice, but for a little while it's just them.
Too soon, Wei Wuxian's hair is clean and tangle free. Lan Wangji forces himself to set the comb aside, to get up and retrieve towels for them.
Wei Ying smiles at him as Lan Wangji reaches for A-Yuan. He takes the boy in his arms and sets to drying him off and dressing him while Wei Wuxian gets out of the tub. He very carefully does not think about anything else happening in the room behind him. Now is not the time. There may never be a time for it.
"It's nice to be clean," Wei Wuxian says and steps into his field of vision wearing the darkest robes Lan Wangji could find for him and squeezing his hair with a towel. "I'm not sure I've been this clean since...before."
"Mn," Lan Wangji hums as he finishes dressing A-Yuan, then wraps him in a warm, soft blanket. He seems so small and fragile like this. When they met, his bright smile, like Wei Wuxian's, filled the area around him. It made him seem so much bigger than his small body.
"Thank you, Lan Zhan," Wei Wuxian says softly and leans in to press a kiss to A-Yuan's forehead. Instead of pulling away, he lets his head fall to Lan Wangji's shoulder. "I don't know what I'd do if–" He cuts himself off. "Thank you for letting us in the gates."
Lan Wangji closes his eyes and breathes in, then out again. "Let's get him back to the doctor."
"Yeah," Wei Wuxian replies and goes to collect his things from the abandoned pile of clothes. It's clear he didn't carry much with him, just a single qiankun bag. "I would say to just burn these clothes, but I probably need them."
"I will send everything to be washed tomorrow," Lan Wangji promises. It's not a lie, but he will also send someone to Caiyi Town with money and instructions to buy some simple, black robes and bring them back.
They move back into the other room and Lan Wangji carefully lays A-Yuan back down on the bed and steps back to give the doctor access. He and Wei Wuxian both stand back and watch as he applies the poultice to A-Yuan's chest.
"Remove this on the hour," the doctor says. "Give him broth at any time you can get him to take it. He's underweight and that won't help him get better."
"I...is. Is it just because of the illness?" Wei Wuxian asks. Lan Wangji can see his hands clench on the qiankun bag.
"Mostly," the doctor replies. "If he hadn't gotten ill, he would still be in the healthy range, if not exactly where I would usually like to see a boy his age."
"So...he hasn't been going hungry?" Wei Wuxian asks.
"No, Wei-gongzi," the doctor says gently. "You have done well. How often have you eaten less so he could have his fill, hm?"
Wei Wuxian looks to the side and doesn't answer. Lan Wangji feels his breath catch in his throat.
"That's what I thought. Make sure Wei-gongzi eats small meals frequently, Hanguang-Jun," the doctor tells him.
"I will," Lan Wangji promises. Nothing about this is right or fair. It hits him square in the chest that it has never been right or fair.
"I will be back in the morning unless you send for me sooner," the doctor says.
"Goodnight," Lan Wangji says and bows to him.
Wei Wuxian does the same. "Thank you for helping him."
"There is no need to thank me for helping a sick child," the doctor says. "I would never have turned him away."
He's gone then, leaving the two of them alone with A-Yuan.
Wei Wuxian takes a deep breath and lets it out again. "You should go back to bed, Lan Zhan. I've kept you awake long enough."
Lan Wangji shakes his head. "I will stay with you and A-Yuan."
"I'm too tired to argue," Wei Wuxian says. He's clearly also too tired to regulate his expression because he looks distinctly relieved.
Lan Wangji retrieves another mat from the cupboard and sets it out as Wei Wuxian sinks down to sit on the floor next to A-Yuan's bed and pulls out a small, colorful stuffed creature. The colors are still bright, despite being well-loved. There's a crinkling sound under his fingers and Wei Wuxian turns it over. There is a folded piece of paper pinned to it.
He frowns and takes the paper, then tucks the stuffed creature under A-Yuan's arm.
Lan Wangji stands at the foot of A-Yuan's bed and watches Wei Wuxian's face as he unfolds the paper and reads what's inside. His expression moves from shock, to a grief so deep it makes Lan Wangji's heart ache, to anger.
"Fuck that. I won't do it," Wei Wuxian says darkly and throws the letter directly into the fire in the corner of the room.
*
For the first time in months, Wei Wuxian feels almost content. Almost happy. A-Yuan is receiving the care he needs to get better and Lan Wangji is with him.
He sinks to the floor to get A-Yuan's stuffed toy from his bag so he has something comforting and familiar with him if he wakes up and Wei Wuxian isn't right there. When he pulls it from the qiankun pouch there's a crinkle of paper under his fingers. His name is written on top in Wen Qing's neat hand.
